CSE & NMCG. (2024). Waste to Worth: Managing India's Urban Water Crisis through Wastewater Reuse. 35 case studies, 16 cities, 7 states. Only 28% treated, 72% untreated.
IndiaSpend. (2024). Why India Needs to Urgently Rehaul Sewage Treatment Plans. 72B L/day sewage, 37% capacity, 28% treated. 73% decline in per capita water since 1950.
SANDRP. (2025). India's Non-functional Sewage Treatment Plants. Only 29% of 45,000 MLD treated. 61/154 Maharashtra STPs non-compliant. NGT ₹80,000 Cr fines.
Down to Earth. (2024). Policy and Governance Roadblocks to Treated Water Reuse. Only 11/28 states have reuse policies. Fragmented responsibility across MoHUA, CPCB, SPCBs, ULBs.
PIB/MoHUA. (2021). AMRUT 2.0 Framework. ₹2.77 lakh Cr outlay. 20% reuse mandate for cities >10K population. 40% industrial reuse at state level.
Down to Earth. (2024). Tanker Economy Revealed: Nexus Between Water Mafia and Politicians. Bengaluru 3,500+ tankers, ₹1,200-3,000/12,000L. Ward engineers control permits.
Water Alternatives. (2014). Mafias in the Waterscape: Urban Informality in Bangalore. Political nexus with tanker operators. ₹8,000-12,000 daily revenue per tanker.
Down to Earth. (2024). India's Water Crisis: The Role of Wastewater Reuse and Circularity. State-level reuse data: Delhi 49%, Karnataka 43%, Rajasthan 29%, Haryana 15%, Maharashtra 17%.

Banerjee, I. (2021). Problems of Urban Self-governance in India. Nagarlok, IIPA. Only 11/31 states transferred all 18 functions. Municipal own revenue 42.7% nationally. 35% average staff vacancy. Election delays, parastatal interference, fiscal dependency.

CAG. (2021). Performance Audit on Efficacy of Implementation of 74th CAA with Focus on 3Fs. Odisha audit: 112/114 ULBs no elections for up to 9 years. Own revenue 11.22%. Ward committees not constituted. 13/18 functions have overlapping jurisdiction with parastatals.

Janaagraha. (2023). ASICS 2023: Annual Survey of India's City-Systems Data Book. 1,484/4,766 city councils inactive (31%). No functional ward committees in AP, Bihar, Delhi, UP, WB. Councillor salary ₹2,500-25,000/month vs MLA ₹50K-1.83L. Municipal election turnout 10-20% lower than state elections.
UNEP. (2024). Food Waste Index Report 2024. India: 78.2 million tonnes food wasted annually (₹92,000 Cr value). 64.1 MT CO₂e emissions from post-harvest losses. Per capita waste 50 kg/year.

NCCD. (2023). All India Cold Chain Infrastructure Capacity Assessment. Only 500 of 125,000 needed rural packhouses exist. 70% cold storage for potatoes. 9,000 vs 62,000 reefer trucks needed. Horticulture gets <4% cold chain capacity. ₹1.7 lakh crore investment needed.

CACP. (2024). Commission for Agricultural Costs and Prices Reports. MSP covers 23 crops but 95%+ procurement is rice/wheat. Rice/wheat account for 60% of foodgrain area. PDS distributes almost exclusively rice/wheat, limiting millet uptake.

India Water Portal. (2024). Why India's rice and wheat subsidies are drying up our groundwater. MSP policies caused 30% over-production of water-intensive crops. 50% of Punjab groundwater decline attributable to rice procurement. Rice-wheat covers 95% of crop area.

Mongabay India. (2025). The hidden side of millet farming. Millet farmers receive only 33-42% of what rice/wheat farmers get. Income from millet farming could not cover costs in alternate years. Lack of MSP equivalent institutional support.

Springer. (2024). Crop diversification and income of agricultural households in India. Farm income increases by ~13% when households diversify crops. Diversified households have higher access to technical advice, markets, and credit.

TERI. (2018). Economics of Desertification, Land Degradation and Drought in India. ₹2.54 trillion annual loss (~2% GDP) from land degradation. 97.9 Mha (30% of land) degraded. 74 million tonnes nutrients lost annually. $1.73 trillion projected loss by 2050.

Nature Communications. (2022). Solving groundwater depletion in India while achieving food security. Punjab/Haryana aquifer depletion 109 km³/year (world's 2nd most overexploited). Borewells now 80-200 feet vs 30 feet a decade ago. 92-96% withdrawal for irrigation. Punjab spends ₹39,000/ha on rice subsidies. Haryana offers ₹17,500/ha to switch crops.

Springer. (2025). India's fertilizer policies: implications for food security, environmental sustainability, and climate change. NPK ratio 10.9:4.4:1 vs 4:2:1 ideal. ₹1.68 lakh crore fertilizer subsidy (FY25-26). Urea over-subsidization causes nitrogen excess, groundwater nitrate contamination.

Nature/ResearchGate. (2024). Economic impact of FPO membership: empirical evidence from India. 22% higher price realization for FPO members. 39% higher annual agricultural income. 49% lower poverty incidence (0.352 vs 0.691). 31% lower marketing costs.
FSI. (2023). India State of Forest Report 2023. 24,651 sq km dense forest lost (2003-2023), replaced by plantations not natural regeneration. Overall forest cover increase masks quality decline.
Global Forest Watch. (2024). India Forest Loss Data. Forest fires account for 44% of tree cover loss since 2001. Climate change increasing fire frequency. Ground-level fire prevention underfunded.
Yale EPI. (2024). Environmental Performance Index. India ranks 176 of 180 on Nature Conservation Index. Protected Area coverage adequate but management effectiveness poor.

CAG. (2023). Audit of Compensatory Afforestation Fund. ₹66,000+ crore accumulated with poor utilization. CAMPA plantation survival rate only 7.5%. Monoculture plantations don't replicate biodiversity of diverted forests.

Joshi, A.A. et al. (2020). Lantana camara invasion in tiger reserves. Invasive Lantana covers 40% of tiger reserve area. Outcompetes native species; reduces prey habitat. Removal labor-intensive but critical for ecosystem restoration.

MoEFCC. (2024). Human-Wildlife Conflict Report. 2,727 human deaths from elephant attacks (2019-2024). Habitat fragmentation pushing wildlife into human areas. Corridor connectivity critical for reducing conflict.

World Bank. (2024). Natural Capital and Ecosystem Services in India. Ecosystem service decline costs India at least 5.7% of GDP annually. Traditional economic measures overlook environmental costs and natural asset depletion.

WEF. (2024). A third of India's economy relies on nature. One-third of India's GDP depends directly on nature. Corporates need to invest more in natural climate solutions. Nature loss poses grave risk to economic growth.

ScienceDirect. (2024). Quantifying habitat and biodiversity services of Indian forests. Annual forest ecosystem services value: habitat $303B, biodiversity $419B, supporting services $744B. Forest carbon sink value ₹6 lakh crore ($120B) at $5/tonne. Carbon stock: 7,204 million tonnes.

ICAR. (2017). Economic benefits of animal pollination to Indian agriculture. Pollination services worth ₹1,12,615 crore ($22.5B) annually — 8.72% of agricultural value. 51% of crops (108 of 211) depend on animal pollination. Rapeseed/mustard most dependent: ₹19,355 Cr EVP.

PNAS/Centre for Wildlife Studies. (2021). Human casualties are the dominant cost of human-wildlife conflict in India. Elephant conflict: $33,268 per incident total cost. 0.8-1 million hectares crops damaged annually. Government compensation ₹38 Cr/year vs actual losses in hundreds of crores. Value of human life: ₹2.2 Cr vs compensation ₹0.76-8.7 lakh.

Frontiers/IUCN. (2023). Western Ghats ecosystem services valuation. 400 million people depend on Western Ghats for water and food. 30% of Indian species in 5% of land area. Ecosystem services value $612 million (2021). 50% amphibians, 67% fish endemic to region.

Nature/UC Santa Cruz. (2024). Global Flood Protection Benefits of Mangroves. Mangroves provide $65B/year flood protection globally; $855B present value over 100 years. India among top 5 global beneficiaries. 15 million more people would flood annually if mangroves lost.

Mongabay/UNDP. (2024). India's biodiversity finance needs. Conservation needs: ₹81,664 Cr/year (2025-30). Previous spending: ₹32,207 Cr (2018-22 total). Finance gap: ₹49,000+ Cr/year. Biodiversity credit market: $2B by 2030. 20x ROI on nature investment (UNEP).

ORF/MOSPI. (2018). Greening the GDP: Natural capital accounting in India. India's first environmental economic accounts released 2018. NCAVES project pilot testing ecosystem accounting. Green GDP would show lower growth when ecosystem depreciation included.
